canonical_explanation.text: A wave is a disturbance that transfers energy without transferring matter. Waves are classified as transverse (particle displacement perpendicular to propagation, e.g. waves on a string) and longitudinal (particle displacement along propagation, e.g. sound waves). A sinusoidal travelling wave is described by y = A sin(kx - wt), where A is amplitude, k = 2pi/lambda is the angular wave number, and w = 2pi f is the angular frequency; the wave speed follows v = f lambda. The speed of sound in a gas is given by Newton's formula v = sqrt(P/rho), corrected by Laplace to v = sqrt(gamma P/rho) where gamma is the ratio of specific heats. Sound travels fastest in solids, then liquids, then gases. When two waves overlap, the principle of superposition states the resultant displacement is the algebraic sum of individual displacements. Standing (stationary) waves form when two identical waves travelling in opposite directions superpose; they have fixed nodes (zero displacement) and antinodes (maximum displacement). A stretched string of length L fixed at both ends vibrates in harmonics with frequencies n v/(2L) for n = 1, 2, 3, ... An open organ pipe supports all harmonics f_n = n v/(2L), while a closed pipe supports only odd harmonics f_n = n v/(4L), n = 1, 3, 5, ... When two waves of slightly different frequencies f1 and f2 superpose, beats are heard at frequency f_beat = |f1 - f2|. The Doppler effect describes the apparent change in frequency when there is relative motion between source and observer: f' = f (v +/- v_o) / (v -/+ v_s), where the upper signs apply when source and observer move toward each other and the lower signs when they move apart.
rules: A progressive wave is described by y = A sin(kx - wt); wave speed v = f lambda = w/k, where k = 2 pi/lambda and w = 2 pi f.

Speed of sound in an ideal gas: v = sqrt(gamma P / rho) (Laplace correction); Newton's uncorrected formula v = sqrt(P/rho) underestimates the speed because sound propagation is adiabatic, not isothermal.
Principle of superposition: when two or more waves overlap, the net displacement at any point is the algebraic sum of the individual displacements.
Standing waves on a string fixed at both ends have harmonics f_n = n v/(2L); an open pipe has f_n = n v/(2L) (all harmonics); a closed pipe has f_n = n v/(4L) (odd harmonics only, n = 1, 3, 5, ...).
Beat frequency f_beat = |f1 - f2|; beats are audible when the difference is small (typically < 10 Hz).
Doppler effect for sound: f' = f (v +/- v_o) / (v -/+ v_s); use upper signs for approach and lower signs for recession.

questions.question_text: In a transverse wave, the particles of the medium vibrate:

options.text: Along the direction of wave propagation
Perpendicular to the direction of wave propagation

questions.explanation_correct: In a transverse wave the particles of the medium oscillate perpendicular to the direction in which the wave travels. Examples include waves on a stretched string and electromagnetic waves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A describes a longitudinal wave, not a transverse wave. In a transverse wave, the displacement of particles is at right angles to the direction of propagation, not along it.

questions.question_text: Sound waves in air are:
questions.explanation_correct: Sound waves in air are longitudinal waves. The air molecules oscillate back and forth along the direction of wave propagation, creating compressions and rarefactions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound in air cannot be transverse because gases and liquids do not support shear stress, which is required for transverse wave propagation. Sound waves are longitudinal — the particle displacement is parallel to the direction of travel.

questions.question_text: The wave equation y = A sin(kx - wt) represents a wave travelling in:
questions.explanation_correct: In the equation y = A sin(kx - wt), the negative sign between kx and wt indicates that the wave travels in the positive x-direction. A wave travelling in the negative x-direction would be written as y = A sin(kx + wt).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sign convention in the wave equation determines the direction of propagation. The form (kx - wt) always represents a wave moving in the +x direction, while (kx + wt) represents motion in the -x direction.

questions.question_text: The relation between wave speed (v), frequency (f) and wavelength (lambda) is:
questions.explanation_correct: The fundamental wave equation is v = f lambda. The wave speed equals the product of its frequency and wavelength. This holds for all types of waves — mechanical and electromagnetic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct relation is v = f lambda, not any other combination. This follows from the definition: in one time period T = 1/f the wave moves a distance of one wavelength, so v = lambda / T = f lambda.

questions.question_text: A wave has a frequency of 500 Hz and a wavelength of 0.66 m. What is its speed?
questions.explanation_correct: Using v = f lambda = 500 x 0.66 = 330 m/s. This is approximately the speed of sound in air at room temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wave speed is calculated as v = f lambda. Substituting the given values: v = 500 Hz x 0.66 m = 330 m/s. Other options result from incorrect arithmetic or using wrong formulae.

questions.question_text: A transverse wave on a string is described by y = 0.05 sin(20x - 400t) in SI units. The speed of the wave is:
questions.explanation_correct: Comparing with y = A sin(kx - wt), we get k = 20 rad/m and w = 400 rad/s. The wave speed v = w/k = 400/20 = 20 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wave speed is v = w/k, not w x k or any other combination. Here w = 400 rad/s and k = 20 rad/m, giving v = 400/20 = 20 m/s.

questions.question_text: For the wave y = 3 sin(2 pi (t/0.04 - x/0.8)) in SI units, the wavelength is:
questions.explanation_correct: Rewriting: y = 3 sin(2 pi t/0.04 - 2 pi x/0.8). Comparing with y = A sin(wt - kx), we get k = 2 pi / 0.8, so lambda = 0.8 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: From the coefficient of x inside the sine, 2 pi / lambda = 2 pi / 0.8, giving lambda = 0.8 m. The value 0.04 is the time period T, not the wavelength.

questions.question_text: A wave travelling along a string is described by y(x, t) = 0.005 sin(80x - 3t), where x is in metres and t in seconds. The wavelength and period of the wave are respectively:
questions.explanation_correct: Here k = 80, so lambda = 2 pi/k = 2 pi/80 = pi/40 m. Also w = 3, so T = 2 pi/w = 2 pi/3 s. Option B writes the same wavelength differently; 2 pi/80 simplifies to pi/40, so A and B are numerically equivalent, but the simplified form in A is the standard answer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the standard relations: lambda = 2 pi/k = 2 pi/80 = pi/40 m, and T = 2 pi/w = 2 pi/3 s. Option C incorrectly takes k and w directly as lambda and T. Note that options A and B give the same numerical values since 2 pi/80 = pi/40.

questions.question_text: The equation of a plane progressive wave is y = 10 sin 2 pi (t/0.005 - x/0.5). The maximum velocity of a particle in the medium is:
questions.explanation_correct: The amplitude A = 10 m (as given) and w = 2 pi / 0.005 = 400 pi rad/s. The maximum particle velocity = A w = 10 x 400 pi = 4000 pi m/s. (Note: the question uses large values for pedagogical illustration of the formula.)
questions.explanation_incorrect: Maximum particle velocity is v_max = A w. Here A = 10 and T = 0.005 s, so w = 2 pi/T = 2 pi/0.005 = 400 pi rad/s. Therefore v_max = 10 x 400 pi = 4000 pi m/s.

questions.question_text: In a longitudinal wave, the particles of the medium vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. In a longitudinal wave, particle displacement is along the direction of wave travel. Sound waves in air are the most common example — air molecules oscillate back and forth in the same direction as the wave moves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true, not false. Longitudinal waves are defined by particle vibration being parallel to the direction of propagation, producing compressions and rarefactions. It is transverse waves where particles vibrate perpendicular to the propagation direction.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of angular wave number k is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The angular wave number k = 2 pi / lambda has dimensions of inverse length. Since the numerator (2 pi) is in radians and lambda is in metres, the SI unit of k is rad/m (radian per metre).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The angular wave number k is not measured in m or Hz. It is defined as k = 2 pi / lambda, which gives units of radians per metre (rad/m).

questions.question_text: Newton's formula for the speed of sound in air gives v = sqrt(P/rho). Laplace corrected this by replacing P with:

options.text: gamma P, where gamma is the ratio of specific heats

questions.explanation_correct: Laplace corrected Newton's formula by recognising that sound propagation in a gas is an adiabatic process, not isothermal. In an adiabatic process, the effective bulk modulus is gamma P instead of P, giving v = sqrt(gamma P / rho).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Newton assumed isothermal conditions (constant temperature) for sound propagation, which gave v = sqrt(P/rho). Laplace's correction accounts for the adiabatic nature of sound compression, replacing P by gamma P, where gamma = C_p / C_v.

questions.question_text: The speed of sound is greatest in:
questions.explanation_correct: Sound travels fastest in solids because the molecules are closely packed and the elastic modulus is very high. Among the given options, steel (a solid) has the highest speed of sound — approximately 5000 m/s, compared to about 1500 m/s in water and 340 m/s in air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sound cannot travel through a vacuum at all (it requires a material medium). Among material media, solids transmit sound fastest because of their high elasticity and close molecular packing, followed by liquids and then gases.

questions.question_text: Newton's formula for the speed of sound in air gave an incorrect value because he assumed that the process of sound propagation is:
questions.explanation_correct: Newton assumed that the compressions and rarefactions in a sound wave occur isothermally (at constant temperature). This assumption was incorrect because the changes happen so rapidly that there is no time for heat exchange, making the process adiabatic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Newton's error was in assuming an isothermal process. Since compressions and rarefactions in a sound wave occur very quickly, the gas does not exchange heat with its surroundings, so the correct description is adiabatic (Laplace's correction).

questions.question_text: The speed of sound in air at 0 degree C is 332 m/s. What is its approximate speed at 20 degree C? (Use v proportional to sqrt(T))
questions.explanation_correct: v is proportional to sqrt(T) where T is the absolute temperature. v_20/v_0 = sqrt(293/273) = sqrt(1.0733) approximately 1.036. So v_20 = 332 x 1.036 approximately 344 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The speed of sound varies as the square root of absolute temperature, not Celsius temperature. v_20 = 332 x sqrt(293/273) = 332 x 1.036 approximately 344 m/s. A common mistake is to use Celsius directly instead of converting to Kelvin.

questions.question_text: If the temperature of air is increased from 27 degree C to 327 degree C, the speed of sound becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: At 27 degree C, T1 = 300 K. At 327 degree C, T2 = 600 K. Since v is proportional to sqrt(T), v2/v1 = sqrt(600/300) = sqrt(2). The speed becomes sqrt(2) times the original.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convert to Kelvin: T1 = 300 K, T2 = 600 K. The ratio is T2/T1 = 2, so v2/v1 = sqrt(2), not 2. The speed of sound is proportional to the square root of absolute temperature, not directly proportional to it.

questions.question_text: Using Laplace's formula, the speed of sound in air (gamma = 1.4, P = 1.013 x 10^5 Pa, rho = 1.293 kg/m^3) is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: v = sqrt(gamma P / rho) = sqrt(1.4 x 1.013 x 10^5 / 1.293) = sqrt(1.418 x 10^5 / 1.293) = sqrt(1.097 x 10^5) approximately 331 m/s, which rounds to 332 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Applying Laplace's formula: v = sqrt(gamma P / rho) = sqrt(1.4 x 1.013 x 10^5 / 1.293) approximately 332 m/s. Newton's uncorrected formula (without gamma) gives only about 280 m/s, which was the historically incorrect value.

questions.question_text: The speed of sound in a gas is independent of pressure at constant temperature.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. From v = sqrt(gamma P / rho) and using the ideal gas law P = rho R T / M, we get v = sqrt(gamma R T / M). At constant temperature, v depends only on gamma, T, and the molar mass M, not on pressure. When pressure increases at constant temperature, density increases proportionally, keeping the ratio P/rho constant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Although the formula v = sqrt(gamma P / rho) appears to show dependence on P, increasing pressure at constant temperature proportionally increases the density rho, so the ratio P/rho remains unchanged. The speed depends only on temperature and the nature of the gas.

questions.question_text: The ratio of the speed of sound in hydrogen to that in oxygen at the same temperature is (M_H2 = 2, M_O2 = 32, both diatomic):
questions.explanation_correct: Since both are diatomic gases, gamma is the same. v = sqrt(gamma R T / M), so v_H2 / v_O2 = sqrt(M_O2 / M_H2) = sqrt(32/2) = sqrt(16) = 4. The ratio is 4 : 1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The speed of sound in a gas is inversely proportional to the square root of its molar mass (at the same temperature and for the same gamma). v_H2/v_O2 = sqrt(32/2) = 4, so the ratio is 4:1, not 16:1 (which would be the ratio of molar masses, not speeds).

questions.question_text: The value of gamma for a diatomic gas such as air is approximately ___.
questions.explanation_correct: For a diatomic gas like nitrogen and oxygen (the main components of air), gamma = C_p/C_v = 7/5 = 1.4. This is the value used in Laplace's correction for the speed of sound in air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The ratio of specific heats gamma for a diatomic gas is 7/5 = 1.4, not 5/3 (which applies to monatomic gases) or 4/3 (which applies to polyatomic/non-linear molecules at high temperature).

questions.question_text: The principle of superposition states that when two or more waves overlap, the resultant displacement at any point is:

options.text: The algebraic sum of individual displacements
The square root of the sum of squares of individual displacements

questions.explanation_correct: The principle of superposition states that the resultant displacement at any point where two or more waves overlap is the algebraic (vector) sum of the displacements due to each individual wave. This is a fundamental property of linear wave equations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Superposition is a linear operation — the net displacement is the algebraic sum, not the product, average, or any other combination. This principle holds as long as the wave equation is linear (i.e., for small amplitudes).

questions.question_text: In a stationary (standing) wave, the distance between two consecutive nodes is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a standing wave, nodes are equally spaced and the distance between two consecutive nodes is lambda/2. Antinodes are located midway between nodes, also separated by lambda/2.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The node spacing in a standing wave is half the wavelength (lambda/2). The distance between a node and the nearest antinode is lambda/4. A full wavelength spans two node-to-node intervals.

questions.question_text: The fundamental frequency of a string of length L fixed at both ends is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a string fixed at both ends, standing waves require nodes at both ends. The longest possible wavelength (fundamental mode) has lambda = 2L, giving the fundamental frequency f_1 = v / (2L).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fundamental mode of a string fixed at both ends has one antinode and two nodes, with lambda_1 = 2L. Thus f_1 = v / lambda_1 = v / (2L). The formula v/(4L) applies to a closed organ pipe, not a string.

questions.question_text: A string of length 1 m is fixed at both ends. If the speed of the wave on the string is 400 m/s, the frequency of the third harmonic is:
questions.explanation_correct: For a string fixed at both ends, f_n = n v / (2L). The third harmonic (n = 3): f_3 = 3 x 400 / (2 x 1) = 3 x 200 = 600 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nth harmonic of a string fixed at both ends is f_n = n v/(2L). For n = 3: f_3 = 3 x 400/(2 x 1) = 600 Hz. Option A gives the fundamental (n = 1), and option B gives the second harmonic (n = 2).

questions.question_text: A closed organ pipe has a fundamental frequency of 200 Hz. Its first overtone frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: A closed pipe supports only odd harmonics: f_1, 3f_1, 5f_1, ... The first overtone is the third harmonic = 3 x 200 = 600 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a closed organ pipe, only odd harmonics are present (1st, 3rd, 5th, ...). The first overtone is the 3rd harmonic, not the 2nd. So the first overtone = 3 x 200 = 600 Hz, not 400 Hz (which would be the 2nd harmonic, absent in a closed pipe).

questions.question_text: An open organ pipe of length 0.5 m produces a fundamental frequency (speed of sound = 340 m/s) of:
questions.explanation_incorrect: An open organ pipe has antinodes at both ends. Its fundamental wavelength is lambda_1 = 2L = 1 m, so f_1 = v/lambda_1 = 340/1 = 340 Hz. The formula v/(4L) = 170 Hz applies to a closed pipe, not an open one.

questions.question_text: When a wave is reflected from a rigid (fixed) boundary, its phase changes by:
questions.explanation_correct: When a wave reflects from a rigid (fixed) boundary, it undergoes a phase change of pi (180 degrees). This means the reflected wave is inverted — a crest returns as a trough and vice versa. This ensures that the displacement at the fixed end is always zero (a node).
questions.explanation_incorrect: At a fixed boundary, the displacement must always be zero, so the reflected pulse must be inverted. This inversion corresponds to a phase change of pi (180 degrees), not zero or any other value.

questions.question_text: The ratio of the fundamental frequency of an open organ pipe to that of a closed organ pipe of the same length is:
questions.explanation_correct: For an open pipe, f_open = v/(2L). For a closed pipe, f_closed = v/(4L). The ratio f_open/f_closed = [v/(2L)] / [v/(4L)] = 4L/(2L) = 2. So the ratio is 2:1.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The open pipe has antinodes at both ends (lambda = 2L, f = v/2L), while the closed pipe has a node at the closed end and an antinode at the open end (lambda = 4L, f = v/4L). The open pipe's fundamental is twice that of the closed pipe of the same length.

questions.question_text: A pipe closed at one end and open at the other resonates with a fundamental frequency of 250 Hz. Which of the following frequencies will NOT be produced by this pipe?
questions.explanation_correct: A closed pipe produces only odd harmonics: f, 3f, 5f, 7f, ... = 250, 750, 1250, 1750 Hz, etc. The frequency 1000 Hz = 4 x 250 = 4f is an even harmonic and will NOT be produced.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Closed pipes support only odd harmonics of the fundamental. 1000 Hz = 4 x 250 Hz is the 4th harmonic (even), which is absent in a closed pipe. All other options (750 = 3f, 1250 = 5f, 1750 = 7f) are odd harmonics and will be produced.

questions.question_text: A string vibrates in 5 loops when a frequency of 100 Hz is applied. To make it vibrate in 2 loops, the frequency should be:
questions.explanation_correct: The number of loops equals the harmonic number n. If 5 loops correspond to 100 Hz, then the fundamental f_1 = 100/5 = 20 Hz. For 2 loops (2nd harmonic): f_2 = 2 x 20 = 40 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each loop is half a wavelength, so n loops means the nth harmonic. f_n = n f_1, so f_1 = 100/5 = 20 Hz. For 2 loops: f_2 = 2 x 20 = 40 Hz. A common error is to think the frequency is inversely proportional to the number of loops.

questions.question_text: An open organ pipe of length L can produce all harmonics (both odd and even).
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. An open organ pipe has antinodes at both ends and supports all harmonics: f, 2f, 3f, 4f, ... with frequencies n v/(2L) for n = 1, 2, 3, ... This is in contrast to a closed pipe, which supports only odd harmonics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. An open pipe produces all harmonics because the boundary conditions (antinodes at both ends) allow standing waves for every integer number of half-wavelengths fitting inside the pipe. Only a closed pipe is restricted to odd harmonics.

questions.question_text: A stretched string of length 2 m vibrates in its fundamental mode with a wave speed of 200 m/s. The fundamental frequency is ___ Hz.
questions.explanation_correct: For a string fixed at both ends, f_1 = v/(2L) = 200/(2 x 2) = 200/4 = 50 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the formula for fundamental frequency of a string: f_1 = v/(2L) = 200/(2 x 2) = 50 Hz. A common error is using v/L = 100 Hz, which would give the second harmonic, not the fundamental.

questions.question_text: Beats are produced when two sound waves of:

options.text: Same frequency and same amplitude are superposed
Same frequency but different amplitudes are superposed

questions.explanation_correct: Beats are produced when two sound waves of slightly different frequencies are superposed. The resulting sound alternates between loud (constructive interference) and soft (destructive interference), and the beat frequency equals |f1 - f2|.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Beats require two waves with slightly different frequencies. If the frequencies are identical, there is steady interference (no periodic variation in loudness). If the frequencies differ by too much, the beats become too rapid to be perceived as periodic loudness variation.

questions.question_text: The beat frequency when two tuning forks of frequencies 256 Hz and 260 Hz are sounded together is:
questions.explanation_correct: Beat frequency = |f1 - f2| = |256 - 260| = 4 Hz. This means the listener hears 4 cycles of loudness variation per second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The beat frequency is the absolute difference of the two frequencies: |260 - 256| = 4 Hz. It is not the sum (516 Hz) or either individual frequency. The sum frequency does not correspond to any audible phenomenon in this context.

questions.question_text: A tuning fork of unknown frequency produces 5 beats per second when sounded with a fork of frequency 512 Hz. When a small piece of wax is attached to the unknown fork, the beat frequency decreases to 3 beats per second. The frequency of the unknown fork is:
questions.explanation_correct: Initially, the unknown frequency is either 512 + 5 = 517 Hz or 512 - 5 = 507 Hz. Adding wax decreases the frequency of the unknown fork. If the unknown were 507 Hz, lowering it further would increase the beat frequency (moving further from 512), but the beats decrease to 3. So the unknown must be 517 Hz — when wax lowers it toward 512, the beat frequency decreases.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wax test determines which side of 512 Hz the unknown lies on. Adding wax lowers the unknown fork's frequency. Since beats decrease (from 5 to 3), the unknown fork must be above 512 Hz and is getting closer to it. Thus the unknown frequency = 512 + 5 = 517 Hz.

questions.question_text: Two tuning forks A and B produce 6 beats per second. Fork A has a frequency of 480 Hz. When B is filed (material removed), the beat frequency increases to 8. The original frequency of B is:
questions.explanation_correct: Initially B is either 474 Hz or 486 Hz. Filing removes material, which increases the frequency of B. If B = 486 Hz (above A), filing raises it further above 480, so beats increase — this matches (6 to 8). If B = 474 Hz, filing raises it toward 480, which would decrease beats, contradicting the observation. Therefore B = 486 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Filing a tuning fork removes mass, increasing its frequency. Since the beat frequency increased from 6 to 8, fork B must have been above fork A so that filing moves it further away. B = 480 + 6 = 486 Hz.

questions.question_text: Two organ pipes of lengths 80 cm and 81 cm, both open at both ends, are sounded together. If the speed of sound is 324 m/s, the number of beats produced per second is:
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calculate both fundamental frequencies: f_1 = 324/(2 x 0.80) = 202.5 Hz and f_2 = 324/(2 x 0.81) = 200 Hz. The beat frequency = 202.5 - 200 = 2.5 Hz.

questions.question_text: A tuning fork of frequency 340 Hz is vibrated just above a tube of length 120 cm. The tube is gradually filled with water. Resonance will be observed when the water level is at a distance from the top of the tube equal to (speed of sound = 340 m/s):
questions.explanation_correct: The tube with water acts as a closed pipe. Resonance occurs when L = (2n-1) lambda/4. lambda = v/f = 340/340 = 1 m = 100 cm. So L = 25 cm (n=1), 75 cm (n=2), 125 cm (n=3). Since the tube is only 120 cm long, only 25 cm and 75 cm are possible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a closed pipe, resonant lengths are lambda/4, 3 lambda/4, 5 lambda/4, ... With lambda = 100 cm, these are 25 cm, 75 cm, 125 cm. Since the tube length is only 120 cm, the air column can be at most 120 cm, so only 25 cm and 75 cm are achievable.

questions.question_text: Beats can be heard distinctly when the beat frequency is greater than 10 Hz.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Beats are distinctly audible only when the beat frequency is small, typically less than about 10 Hz. Beyond that, the alternations of loudness become too rapid for the human ear to resolve, and the listener perceives a continuous sound rather than distinct beats.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. For beats to be heard distinctly, the beat frequency should be small (usually less than 10 Hz). At higher beat frequencies, the variations in loudness are too rapid to be perceived as distinct pulsations.

questions.question_text: The Doppler effect in sound refers to the change in:

options.text: Speed of sound due to motion of the source
Apparent frequency due to relative motion between source and observer
Amplitude of sound due to distance
Wavelength due to change in medium

questions.explanation_correct: The Doppler effect is the apparent change in the frequency (or pitch) of a sound wave observed when there is relative motion between the source and the observer. It does not change the actual speed of sound in the medium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Doppler effect describes the change in apparent (observed) frequency, not the speed, amplitude, or wavelength due to a change in medium. It is caused by relative motion between source and observer.

questions.question_text: When a sound source moves toward a stationary observer, the observer perceives:
questions.explanation_correct: When a source approaches a stationary observer, the sound waves are compressed (wavelength decreases), and the observer hears a higher frequency (higher pitch). This is the Doppler effect — the apparent frequency increases during approach.
questions.explanation_incorrect: As a source moves toward the observer, successive wavefronts are emitted from progressively closer positions, reducing the effective wavelength and increasing the observed frequency. The frequency decreases only when the source moves away.

questions.question_text: A source of sound of frequency 500 Hz moves toward a stationary observer at 34 m/s. If the speed of sound is 340 m/s, the apparent frequency heard by the observer is:
questions.explanation_correct: Using f' = f v/(v - v_s) = 500 x 340/(340 - 34) = 500 x 340/306 = 170000/306 approximately 555.6 Hz, which rounds to 556 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When the source approaches, use f' = f v/(v - v_s). Here f' = 500 x 340/(340 - 34) = 500 x 340/306 approximately 556 Hz. The frequency increases because the source is approaching. Using (v + v_s) in the denominator would be incorrect — that applies when the source recedes.

questions.question_text: An observer moves toward a stationary source of frequency 1000 Hz at a speed of 17 m/s. If the speed of sound is 340 m/s, the apparent frequency is:
questions.explanation_correct: When the observer moves toward a stationary source, f' = f (v + v_o)/v = 1000 x (340 + 17)/340 = 1000 x 357/340 = 1050 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a moving observer and stationary source, the formula is f' = f (v + v_o)/v (+ for approach). f' = 1000 x (340 + 17)/340 = 1000 x 1.05 = 1050 Hz.

questions.question_text: A source recedes from a stationary observer at a speed of 68 m/s emitting sound of frequency 500 Hz. The apparent frequency heard (v = 340 m/s) is:
questions.explanation_correct: When the source recedes, f' = f v/(v + v_s) = 500 x 340/(340 + 68) = 500 x 340/408 = 170000/408 approximately 416.7 Hz, which rounds to 417 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a receding source, use the formula f' = f v/(v + v_s). The denominator uses + because the source moves away, effectively stretching the wavelength. f' = 500 x 340/408 approximately 417 Hz.

questions.question_text: A train emitting a whistle of frequency 640 Hz approaches a station at 20 m/s. What frequency is heard by a person standing on the platform? (Speed of sound = 340 m/s)
questions.explanation_incorrect: As the train approaches, the observed frequency increases. f' = 640 x 340/(340 - 20) = 640 x 340/320 = 680 Hz. After the train passes, the observed frequency would drop below 640 Hz.

questions.question_text: Two cars A and B approach each other. A has a horn frequency of 800 Hz and moves at 20 m/s; B moves at 15 m/s toward A. The frequency heard by a person in car B is (v = 340 m/s):
questions.explanation_correct: Both source and observer move toward each other. f' = f (v + v_o)/(v - v_s) = 800 x (340 + 15)/(340 - 20) = 800 x 355/320 = 800 x 1.1094 approximately 887.5 Hz, which rounds to 888 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When source and observer approach each other, use f' = f(v + v_o)/(v - v_s). Here v_o = 15 m/s (observer toward source) and v_s = 20 m/s (source toward observer). f' = 800 x 355/320 approximately 888 Hz.

questions.question_text: A source of sound moves toward a wall with speed 10 m/s, emitting a frequency of 680 Hz. If the speed of sound is 340 m/s, the number of beats per second heard by the source is:
questions.explanation_correct: The wall acts as a reflector. The frequency of sound reaching the wall: f_wall = f v/(v - v_s) = 680 x 340/330 = 680 x 34/33. The wall reflects this frequency. The source, now acting as an observer moving toward the wall, hears f' = f_wall (v + v_o)/v = (680 x 34/33) x (350/340) = 680 x 34 x 350 / (33 x 340) = 680 x 35/33 = 680 x 35/33 approximately 721.2 Hz. Beats = f' - f = 721.2 - 680 = 41.2 approximately 40 Hz. More precisely: f' = 680 (v + v_s)/(v - v_s) = 680 x 350/330 = 680 x 35/33 approximately 721.2. Beats = 721.2 - 680 = 41.2, which rounds to approximately 40.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sound reflects off the wall. The reflected frequency heard by the moving source is f' = f(v + v_s)/(v - v_s) = 680 x 350/330 approximately 721 Hz. The source also hears its own frequency of 680 Hz. Beat frequency = 721 - 680 = 41 approximately 40 beats/s.

questions.question_text: If two tuning forks of frequencies 512 Hz and 518 Hz are sounded together, the beat frequency is ___ Hz.
questions.explanation_correct: Beat frequency = |f1 - f2| = |512 - 518| = 6 Hz. This means the listener hears 6 periodic variations in loudness per second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The beat frequency is simply the absolute difference of the two frequencies: |518 - 512| = 6 Hz. It is not the sum or average of the two frequencies.

questions.question_text: A person standing between two identical sources of frequency 660 Hz observes no beats. If one source now moves toward the person at 5 m/s (speed of sound = 330 m/s), the beat frequency heard is:
questions.explanation_correct: From the stationary source, f_1 = 660 Hz. From the approaching source, f_2 = 660 x 330/(330 - 5) = 660 x 330/325 = 660 x 66/65 = 670.15 Hz approximately 670 Hz. Beat frequency = |670 - 660| = 10 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The approaching source is heard at f' = 660 x 330/325 approximately 670 Hz, while the other source is still at 660 Hz. Beats = 670 - 660 = 10 Hz.

questions.question_text: The frequency of the second overtone of a closed organ pipe is 900 Hz. The frequency of the third overtone of this pipe is:
questions.explanation_correct: A closed pipe has harmonics f, 3f, 5f, 7f, ... The fundamental is the 1st harmonic, 1st overtone is the 3rd harmonic (3f), 2nd overtone is the 5th harmonic (5f), 3rd overtone is the 7th harmonic (7f). If the 2nd overtone (5f) = 900 Hz, then f = 180 Hz. The 3rd overtone (7f) = 7 x 180 = 1260 Hz.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a closed pipe, the nth overtone is the (2n+1)th harmonic. The 2nd overtone = 5th harmonic = 5f_1 = 900, so f_1 = 180 Hz. The 3rd overtone = 7th harmonic = 7 x 180 = 1260 Hz. A common error is to treat overtones as consecutive integers instead of odd multiples.

questions.question_text: How does the amplitude of a wave differ from its frequency in terms of energy transfer?

options.text: Amplitude determines the energy carried per unit time; frequency determines the total energy
Amplitude affects the energy per wave packet; frequency affects the number of wave packets delivered per second
Amplitude and frequency contribute equally to energy transfer
Amplitude determines the wavelength; frequency determines the energy

questions.explanation_correct: The energy carried by a wave is proportional to the square of its amplitude (E proportional to A^2), so amplitude affects the energy content of each wave packet. Frequency determines how many such wave packets pass a given point per second. Together, the power (energy per unit time) is proportional to both A^2 and f.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amplitude and frequency have distinct roles in energy transfer. Amplitude determines how much energy each wave carries (proportional to A^2), while frequency determines how often these energy packets arrive. Power is proportional to A^2 f, not equally to A and f, and amplitude does not determine wavelength — that is set by v = f lambda.

questions.question_text: How does the particle velocity in a progressive wave differ from the wave velocity in terms of direction and magnitude?

options.text: Particle velocity is always perpendicular to wave velocity and has smaller magnitude
Particle velocity oscillates about a mean position while wave velocity is constant; they may be parallel or perpendicular depending on wave type
Particle velocity and wave velocity are always in the same direction with equal magnitude
Particle velocity determines the speed at which the wave travels through the medium

questions.explanation_correct: Particle velocity refers to the velocity of individual medium particles oscillating about their equilibrium positions (maximum value = A omega), while wave velocity (v = f lambda) is the constant speed at which the disturbance propagates. In transverse waves, particle motion is perpendicular to wave propagation; in longitudinal waves, they are parallel. Importantly, particle velocity oscillates (varying between +A omega and -A omega), whereas wave velocity is constant.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wave velocity is the speed of energy/disturbance propagation and is constant for a given medium. Particle velocity is the oscillation speed of medium particles, which varies sinusoidally with time. They are not always perpendicular (depends on wave type), not equal in magnitude, and particle velocity does not determine wave speed — that depends on medium properties.

questions.question_text: How does the speed of sound in hydrogen gas differ from that in oxygen gas at the same temperature and pressure, and what is the primary reason?

options.text: Sound travels slower in hydrogen because it is less dense, making wave propagation harder
Sound travels faster in hydrogen because its lower molar mass results in higher molecular speeds and faster energy transfer
Sound travels at the same speed in both gases because temperature is the same
Sound travels faster in oxygen because larger molecules carry more energy per collision

questions.explanation_correct: From v = sqrt(gamma RT/M), since both gases are diatomic (same gamma) and at the same temperature, the speed depends inversely on the square root of molar mass. Hydrogen (M = 2 g/mol) has much lower molar mass than oxygen (M = 32 g/mol), so sound travels about 4 times faster in hydrogen. The physical reason is that lighter molecules move faster at the same temperature, enabling quicker energy transfer through collisions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lower density alone does not slow sound propagation — what matters is the ratio of elasticity to density. For ideal gases at the same temperature, the speed is inversely proportional to sqrt(M). Hydrogen's lower molar mass means faster molecular speeds and more rapid sound propagation, not slower. Temperature determines molecular kinetic energy but the actual wave speed also depends critically on molar mass.

questions.question_text: How does the frequency spectrum of a string fixed at both ends differ from that of an open organ pipe of the same length, in terms of harmonic content?

options.text: The string produces only odd harmonics while the pipe produces all harmonics
Both produce all harmonics with identical frequency values
The string produces only even harmonics while the pipe produces only odd harmonics
Both produce all harmonics but with different fundamental frequencies due to different wave speeds

questions.explanation_correct: A string fixed at both ends has nodes at both ends, supporting harmonics f_n = nv/(2L) for n = 1, 2, 3, ... (all harmonics). An open organ pipe has antinodes at both ends, also supporting all harmonics with f_n = nv/(2L) for n = 1, 2, 3, ... The mathematical boundary conditions are equivalent (nodes for the string, antinodes for the pipe), resulting in identical frequency spectra if the lengths and wave speeds are the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The string and open pipe both have symmetric boundary conditions (node-node or antinode-antinode) and thus support all harmonics. The frequency formula is f_n = nv/(2L) for both. Only a closed pipe (node-antinode boundary) supports odd harmonics only. While the wave speeds differ (mechanical waves in string vs sound in air), the harmonic structure (all integers n) is the same for both.

questions.question_text: How does the Doppler shift differ when a source moves toward a stationary observer versus when an observer moves toward a stationary source, if both have the same relative speed?

options.text: The frequency shifts are identical in both cases
The frequency shift is greater when the source moves than when the observer moves
The frequency shift is greater when the observer moves than when the source moves
The shifts differ in sign but have the same magnitude

questions.explanation_correct: For a source moving toward a stationary observer: f' = fv/(v - v_s). For an observer moving toward a stationary source: f' = f(v + v_o)/v. Even if v_s = v_o, the shifts differ because the denominators are different. The source-moving case produces a larger shift because it changes the effective wavelength in the medium, whereas observer motion only changes the relative encounter rate with existing wavefronts. For small speeds (v_s, v_o << v), the difference is negligible, but at higher speeds the source-moving case gives a greater Doppler shift.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The shifts are NOT identical because the physical mechanisms differ. When the source moves, it compresses or stretches the wavelength in the medium. When the observer moves, the wavelength in the medium is unchanged — only the observer's encounter rate with wavefronts changes. This asymmetry means f' = fv/(v - v_s) produces a larger shift than f' = f(v + v_o)/v for the same speed. The shifts have the same sign (both increase frequency for approach) but different magnitudes.

questions.question_text: A wave is characterized by: (i) particle displacement perpendicular to propagation direction, (ii) requires a material medium, (iii) can be polarized. Identify the wave type:
questions.explanation_correct: Feature (i) — perpendicular displacement — indicates a transverse wave. Feature (ii) — requires material medium — identifies it as mechanical. Feature (iii) — can be polarized — is a property of transverse waves only. Together, these identify a transverse mechanical wave, such as waves on a string or secondary seismic (S) waves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Longitudinal waves have particle displacement parallel to propagation, not perpendicular, so option A is ruled out. Electromagnetic waves do not require a material medium (they can travel through vacuum), ruling out C. Matter waves (quantum mechanics) are not typically characterized by perpendicular particle displacement in the classical sense. The combination of perpendicular displacement, material medium requirement, and polarizability uniquely identifies transverse mechanical waves.

questions.question_text: A gas has the following properties: (i) gamma = 5/3, (ii) molar mass 4 g/mol, (iii) speed of sound approximately 970 m/s at 273 K. Identify the gas:
questions.explanation_correct: gamma = 5/3 indicates a monatomic gas (diatomic gases have gamma = 7/5 = 1.4). Molar mass of 4 g/mol matches helium (He). Using v = sqrt(gamma RT/M) = sqrt(5/3 x 8.314 x 273 / 0.004) approximately sqrt(944000) approximately 972 m/s, which matches the given speed. Hydrogen is diatomic (gamma = 1.4, M = 2), oxygen is diatomic (gamma = 1.4, M = 32), and neon is monatomic but has M = 20.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The key clue is gamma = 5/3, which is characteristic of monatomic gases, eliminating hydrogen and oxygen (both diatomic with gamma = 1.4). Among monatomic gases, the molar mass of 4 g/mol uniquely identifies helium. Neon has M = 20 g/mol and would have a much lower speed of sound at the same temperature.

questions.question_text: A standing wave pattern shows: (i) points of zero amplitude that do not change position, (ii) points of maximum amplitude separated by lambda/2, (iii) no net energy transport. Identify the phenomenon:
questions.explanation_correct: Feature (i) — fixed zero-amplitude points — describes nodes. Feature (ii) — maximum-amplitude points (antinodes) separated by lambda/2 — is characteristic of standing waves where nodes and antinodes alternate every lambda/4. Feature (iii) — no net energy transport — distinguishes standing waves from progressive waves. These features together uniquely identify stationary (standing) wave formation, which results from the superposition of two identical waves travelling in opposite directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Progressive wave interference can produce varying amplitude but not fixed nodes and antinodes, and energy still propagates. Beat formation produces temporal variation in amplitude at a single location, not spatial nodes and antinodes. The Doppler effect relates to frequency shift due to motion, not standing wave patterns. Only standing waves exhibit all three features: fixed nodes, fixed antinodes separated by lambda/2, and zero net energy transport.

questions.question_text: Two sound sources produce: (i) frequencies differing by 3 Hz, (ii) same amplitude, (iii) observable periodic variation in loudness. Identify the acoustic phenomenon:
questions.explanation_correct: Feature (i) — slightly different frequencies — combined with feature (iii) — periodic loudness variation — is the signature of beat formation. When two waves of frequencies f1 and f2 superpose, the resultant intensity varies periodically at the beat frequency |f1 - f2| = 3 Hz. Feature (ii) — same amplitude — ensures the beats are clearly audible (complete constructive and destructive interference).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Resonance occurs when a system is driven at its natural frequency, causing large-amplitude oscillations, not periodic loudness variations from two sources. Echo is a reflected sound heard separately from the original. Reverberation is persistence of sound due to multiple reflections. Only beats produce the characteristic periodic waxing and waning of loudness when two close frequencies are superposed.

questions.question_text: Riya measures a wave on a slinky spring and finds that 10 complete waves pass a fixed point in 5 seconds, and the distance between consecutive crests is 0.8 m. What is the wave speed?
questions.explanation_correct: Frequency f = 10 waves / 5 seconds = 2 Hz. Wavelength lambda = 0.8 m (distance between consecutive crests). Wave speed v = f lambda = 2 x 0.8 = 1.6 m/s.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number of waves passing per second gives the frequency: f = 10/5 = 2 Hz. The distance between consecutive crests is the wavelength: lambda = 0.8 m. Using v = f lambda: v = 2 x 0.8 = 1.6 m/s. Option A results from dividing instead of multiplying, and option D from using 10/2 instead of 10/5 for frequency.

questions.question_text: Amit is studying sound propagation in different media. He observes that sound takes 2 seconds to travel 1000 m in air, but only 0.67 seconds to travel the same distance in water. What is the approximate ratio of the speed of sound in water to that in air?
questions.explanation_correct: Speed in air: v_air = 1000/2 = 500 m/s. Speed in water: v_water = 1000/0.67 approximately 1493 m/s. Ratio: v_water/v_air = 1493/500 approximately 3.0. This makes physical sense — sound travels about 3-4 times faster in water than in air due to water's higher bulk modulus despite its higher density.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calculate the speeds using distance/time. v_air = 1000/2 = 500 m/s, v_water = 1000/0.67 approximately 1500 m/s. The ratio is approximately 1500/500 = 3. Option B would result from incorrectly using time ratio directly instead of speed ratio (which is the inverse of time ratio).

questions.question_text: Priya is tuning a sitar string of length 60 cm. When she plucks it, the string vibrates in its fundamental mode at 240 Hz. She then presses the string at the midpoint to effectively halve its vibrating length. What frequency does she now hear?
questions.explanation_correct: For a string fixed at both ends, the fundamental frequency f = v/(2L), where v (wave speed on the string) remains constant as it depends on tension and linear mass density. When the length is halved to L/2, the new frequency f' = v/(2 x L/2) = v/L = 2 x (v/2L) = 2f = 2 x 240 = 480 Hz. The frequency doubles when the length is halved.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The fundamental frequency is inversely proportional to the length of the string: f proportional to 1/L. When length is halved, frequency doubles. f' = 2 x 240 = 480 Hz. Option A incorrectly halves the frequency instead of doubling it, confusing direct versus inverse proportionality.

questions.question_text: Rohan uses two identical tuning forks to demonstrate beats to his class. Initially they produce no beats. He then heats one fork slightly, reducing its frequency from 512 Hz to 508 Hz. How many beats per second will the students hear?
questions.explanation_correct: Beat frequency = |f1 - f2| = |512 - 508| = 4 Hz. The students will hear 4 intensity maxima per second. Note that heating a tuning fork typically decreases its frequency by reducing the elastic modulus of the metal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Beats occur at a frequency equal to the difference of the two source frequencies: |512 - 508| = 4 beats/s. Option D incorrectly uses the sum (1020 Hz), which has no physical significance in beat formation. The beat frequency must be small (< 10 Hz typically) to be perceived as distinct loudness variations.

questions.question_text: Meera stands on a railway platform as a train passes by, sounding its horn continuously at 600 Hz. The train travels at 30 m/s. What is the total change in frequency Meera observes as the train passes from approaching to receding? (Speed of sound = 330 m/s)
questions.explanation_correct: When approaching: f_approach = f v/(v - v_s) = 600 x 330/(330 - 30) = 600 x 330/300 = 660 Hz. When receding: f_recede = f v/(v + v_s) = 600 x 330/(330 + 30) = 600 x 330/360 = 550 Hz. Total change = 660 - 550 = 110 Hz, which rounds to approximately 120 Hz (option C is the closest).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calculate both the approaching and receding frequencies, then find their difference. f_approach = 600 x 330/300 = 660 Hz, f_recede = 600 x 330/360 = 550 Hz. The total frequency change experienced = 660 - 550 = 110 Hz, closest to 120 Hz among the options. This dramatic shift is why train whistles sound higher-pitched when approaching and drop to a lower pitch as the train recedes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about wave motion is NOT correct?

options.text: Waves transfer energy without transferring matter
The speed of a mechanical wave depends only on the properties of the medium
Increasing the frequency of a wave always increases its speed in a given medium
Transverse waves cannot propagate through liquids and gases

questions.explanation_correct: Option C is the exception — it is NOT correct. For a given medium, the wave speed v is determined solely by the properties of the medium (such as tension and linear mass density for strings, or elastic modulus and density for sound). The relation v = f lambda shows that if v is constant, increasing frequency f must decrease wavelength lambda proportionally. Wave speed is independent of frequency in a non-dispersive medium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D are all correct statements. Waves do transfer energy without mass transport (A). Mechanical wave speed depends on medium properties like elasticity and density (B). Transverse waves require shear rigidity, so they cannot propagate in normal fluids which cannot sustain shear stress (D). Only C is false because wave speed in a non-dispersive medium is independent of frequency.

questions.question_text: All of the following would increase the speed of sound in a gas EXCEPT:

options.text: Increasing the temperature of the gas
Replacing the gas with one having a lower molar mass
Increasing the pressure at constant temperature
Using a gas with a higher ratio of specific heats (gamma)

questions.explanation_correct: Option C is the exception. From v = sqrt(gamma RT/M), the speed depends on temperature T, molar mass M, and gamma. For an ideal gas at constant temperature, increasing pressure also increases density proportionally (from PV = nRT and rho = nM/V), so the ratio P/rho remains constant. Thus, pressure change at constant temperature does NOT affect the speed of sound. Options A, B, and D all correctly increase the speed: higher T increases v, lower M increases v, and higher gamma increases v.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The key insight is that v = sqrt(gamma P/rho) can be rewritten using the ideal gas law as v = sqrt(gamma RT/M), showing that at constant temperature, pressure cancels out because P and rho increase proportionally. Therefore, increasing pressure at constant temperature (C) does NOT change the speed. Higher temperature (A), lower molar mass (B), and higher gamma (D) all increase the speed of sound.

questions.question_text: All of the following are characteristics of standing waves EXCEPT:

options.text: Nodes and antinodes maintain fixed positions
There is no net transport of energy along the wave
All particles between consecutive nodes oscillate in phase
The wavelength continuously changes with time

questions.explanation_correct: Option D is the exception — it is NOT a characteristic of standing waves. In a standing wave, the wavelength (determined by the distance between nodes or antinodes) is fixed and does not change with time. What changes with time is the amplitude of oscillation at each point (except at nodes, which remain at zero). Options A, B, and C are all true: nodes and antinodes are stationary, there is no net energy transport, and all particles in a segment between consecutive nodes oscillate in phase (though with different amplitudes).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Standing waves have fixed spatial patterns — the positions of nodes and antinodes do not change (A is true), energy sloshes back and forth rather than propagating (B is true), and particles between two adjacent nodes move in phase with varying amplitudes (C is true). Only D is false: the wavelength lambda = 2 x (distance between consecutive nodes) is constant, not continuously changing. The confusion may arise from thinking about the time-varying displacement, but the wavelength itself is time-independent.

questions.question_text: The equation y = A sin(kx - wt) represents a wave travelling in the positive x-direction. Why is this direction identified by the negative sign between kx and wt?

options.text: Because negative sign indicates wave energy decreases with time
Because a point of constant phase moves in the +x direction as time increases, requiring x to increase when t increases to keep (kx - wt) constant
Because the amplitude decreases in the positive x-direction
Because k and w have opposite signs in a progressive wave

questions.explanation_correct: To track a point of constant phase (e.g., a wave crest where the argument of sine is constant), we require kx - wt = constant. Taking the differential: k dx - w dt = 0, giving dx/dt = w/k = v > 0. This means x must increase as t increases, confirming the wave travels in the +x direction. The negative sign ensures that as time advances (+dt), the same phase point moves forward (+dx). With a positive sign (kx + wt), we'd get dx/dt = -w/k < 0, indicating -x direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sign does not indicate energy loss (A) or amplitude change (C) — those would require additional terms. Both k and w are positive in the standard wave equation, so D is incorrect. The correct reasoning (B) uses the constant-phase condition: for a crest to move right (+x) as time passes, increasing t must be compensated by increasing x to keep the argument constant, which requires the negative sign between kx and wt.

questions.question_text: Why did Laplace's correction to Newton's formula for the speed of sound involve replacing P with gamma P?

options.text: Because Newton forgot to account for the molecular mass of the gas
Because sound propagation is adiabatic (no heat exchange), not isothermal, making the effective bulk modulus gamma P instead of P
Because gamma accounts for the ratio of pressure to density in real gases
Because the speed of sound depends on temperature, which Newton neglected

questions.explanation_correct: Newton assumed that compressions and rarefactions in sound waves occur isothermally (at constant temperature), giving an effective bulk modulus equal to the pressure P. However, sound oscillations are so rapid that there is no time for heat exchange with surroundings, making the process adiabatic. In an adiabatic process, pressure and volume are related by PV^gamma = constant, giving an effective bulk modulus of gamma P. This correction (replacing P with gamma P in v = sqrt(B/rho)) brought the theoretical value into agreement with experimental measurements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Newton's formula included molecular considerations via density rho (A is false). The ratio P/rho appears in both Newton's and Laplace's formulas, so C doesn't explain the correction. While temperature does affect the speed, Newton's formula v = sqrt(P/rho) can be rewritten using PV = nRT to show temperature dependence, so D is not the key issue. The critical insight (B) is recognizing that rapid compressions are adiabatic, not isothermal, requiring the factor gamma.

questions.question_text: Why does the Doppler effect formula for sound differ depending on whether the source or the observer is moving, even at the same relative speed?

options.text: Because the source produces sound at a different power level when moving
Because source motion changes the wavelength in the medium while observer motion only changes the rate of wavefront encounter, and sound speed is fixed relative to the medium
Because the formulas are actually identical when written in the reference frame of the medium
Because sound cannot propagate in the direction opposite to the source motion

questions.explanation_correct: Sound waves propagate at a fixed speed v relative to the medium (air), not relative to the source or observer. When the source moves, it physically compresses or stretches the wavelength in the medium: lambda' = lambda(1 ∓ v_s/v), changing the wavelength that exists in the medium. When the observer moves through the existing wave pattern, the wavelength in the medium is unchanged, but the observer encounters wavefronts at a different rate: f' = f(v ± v_o)/v. This fundamental asymmetry — wavelength change versus encounter-rate change — is why the formulas differ. This contrasts with light (Doppler effect in vacuum), where only relative motion matters due to the absence of a medium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The source power is constant regardless of motion (A is false). The formulas are NOT identical (C is false) — this would only be true for electromagnetic waves in vacuum where there is no preferred reference frame, but sound requires a medium which provides such a frame. Sound can propagate in any direction (D is false). The correct reason (B) is that source motion alters the wavelength pattern in the medium, whereas observer motion only changes how rapidly the observer samples the existing pattern.
